segments.key_quote: Arjuna, who is guided by the infallible Lord as friend and driver thus satisfied the dear lady by such statements Arjuna satisfied Draupadi then he dressed in armor and armed himself with furious weapons and getting into his chariot he set out to follow Ashwatthama the son of his martial teacher
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the context of the verses, focusing on Arjuna's pursuit of Ashwatthama and Krishna's role as an infallible guide, explaining the meaning of 'Achyutaa'.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing the 17th and 18th verses of the 7th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. From this chapter, the narration of the Bhagavatam by Suta Goswami begins, and the particular incident that is being discussed in this chapter is the son of Drona punished, Ashwatthama is being punished because he beheaded the sleeping sons of Draupadi, the slave of Drona. So the 17th verse: Iti-priyaam Valgvi chitra jal payi Sasaantva itva chut緊 mithra Soottha Anvaadyravat damshita ugradhanva Kapitvajo guru putram ratvena. The meaning of this verse is: Arjuna, who is guided by the infallible Lord as friend and driver, thus satisfied the dear lady by such statements. Arjuna satisfied Draupadi, then he dressed in armor and armed himself with furious weapons, and getting into his chariot, he set out to follow Ashwatthama, the son of his martial teacher. So Ashwatthama had been rejected even by Duryodhana. Duryodhana did not appreciate this unlawful act of Ashwatthama, and Ashwatthama was actually conscious that his life is in danger, so he had gone away somewhere. So Arjuna, who was having Krishna as his friend and driver, here Krishna is described as Achyutaa, infallible Lord. What is the meaning of infallible? He never falls down from his transcendental position.

segments.key_quote: like we the living entities who desire to enjoy materially we give up that spiritual platform on which we are eternally situated in our relationship with Krishna we give up that and we come to the material platform so this is called a a fall a fall down whereas the Supreme Lord and his pure devotees they never fall down even though they come to the material world they are always transcendentally situated
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the concept of 'falling down' from a spiritual platform and contrasts it with the unwavering transcendental position of the Supreme Lord and his devotees.
segments.transcript: unless he is in deep trance state. Like we, the living entities who desire to enjoy materially, we give up that spiritual platform on which we are eternally situated in our relationship with Krishna. We give up that and we come to the material platform, so this is called a fall, a fall down, whereas the Supreme Lord and his pure devotees, they never fall down. Even though they come to the material world, they are always transcendentally situated, whether in the material world or in the spiritual world, or any situation, any time, any place, they are always transiently situated. So Arjuna was guided by the infallible Lord, the Supreme Lord, who is never subject to any deterioration.

segments.key_quote: Ashwathama the murderer of the princess seeing from a great distance Arjuna coming at him with great speed fled in his chariot panic-stricken just to save his life as Brahma fled in fear from Shiva.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the narrative, describing Ashwatthama's fear and flight from Arjuna, drawing a comparison to Brahma fleeing from Shiva.
segments.transcript: He, Arjuna, satisfied Draupadi by making significant statements. Now, in order to punish Ashwathama, Arjuna has dressed himself in armor and armed himself with furious weapons, and he got into his chariot, he set out to follow Ashwathama. The 18th verse: The meaning of this verse is: Ashwathama, the murderer of the princess, seeing from a great distance Arjuna coming at him with great speed, fled in his chariot panic-stricken just to save his life as Brahma fled in fear from Shiva. So Arjuna is trying to capture Ashwathama to punish him, but Ashwathama, on seeing that Arjuna is coming to capture him, Ashwathama is himself going in his chariot running away from Arjuna just to save his life.

segments.summary: The speaker explains the reference to Brahma fleeing from Shiva, recounting the story of Brahma's illusion and Shiva's anger, as described in the Puranas.
segments.transcript: Ashwathama running away in fear. The comparison is made just as Brahma ran away in fear of Lord Shiva. Now Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport that the word Kaha that is used in the last line of this 18th verse. Now here the word Kaha refers to Brahma. Or if it is read as Yathar Kaha, then Arkaha refers to Surya or the sun god. So both those meanings are taken and explained by Prabhupada. According to the reading matter, either Kaha or Arkaha, there are two references in the Puranas. The Acharyas never speculate. They always refer the Shastra and clarify such matters. So there is a reference for Kaha, and there is also a reference for Arkaha. Arkaha refers to the sun god, and Kaha refers to Brahma. So it is said with respect to Kaha being used in this verse, Kaha means Brahma, who once became elude by his daughter and became a woman and began to follow her. This infuriated Shiva, who attacked Brahma with his trident. Brahma fled in fear of his life. This is described in the Puranas elsewhere, that once Brahma became elude by his own daughter. That is the power of the illusory energy, that such an exalted personality as Brahma, even he became illusioned by the sight of his beautiful daughter. He started following her in order to enjoy with her. So that act of Brahma infuriated Shiva. Shiva became very angry. Shiva is also appearing as the son of Brahma, so he became very angry at Brahma. Shiva carries one instrument called Trishur. With that he attacks those who are unlawful, those who are unnecessarily giving trouble to saintly persons. So they deserve to be punished.
